facts.text: Tardigrades can survive being frozen at -272°C (just one degree above absolute zero) for extended periods, but when researchers shot them out of a high-speed gun at over 900 meters per second, they found the microscopic animals could survive impacts up to approximately 900 m/s but died at speeds around 1,000 m/s—establishing the first known "speed limit" for surviving ballistic impact in any organism.
facts.verification_note: Research published in 2021 confirmed tardigrades can survive cryogenic temperatures near absolute zero and separate ballistic impact studies found they survived impacts up to ~900 m/s but died at higher velocities around 1,000 m/s.
facts.image_description: The illustration shows a split-screen composition in a scientific-technical style with dramatic lighting. On the left, a translucent tardigrade glows an ethereal blue-white against a deep indigo background dotted with ice crystals, its eight legs curled in a frozen tun state at -272°C, with a subtle thermometer graphic showing the temperature just above absolute zero. On the right, the same tardigrade is captured mid-flight in a motion-blur streak of orange and red trailing behind it, shot from a sleek metallic ballistic gun, with a speedometer display showing "900 m/s" in green (survival zone) transitioning sharply to "1000 m/s" in red (lethal zone). The tardigrade's characteristic bear-like body with its clawed legs is rendered in semi-transparent detail showing internal structures, while impact shock waves radiate outward in concentric rings, creating a sense of violent motion contrasting with the serene frozen state.
